    Multistage Screening Reveals 3-Substituted Indolin-2-one Derivatives as Novel and Isoform-Selective c-Jun N-terminal Kinase 3 (JNK3) Inhibitors: Implications to Drug Discovery for Potential Treatment of Neurodegenerative Diseases

    Abstract

    Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is one of the most challenging diseases around the world with no effective clinical treatment. Previous studies have suggested c-Jun N-terminal kinase 3 (JNK3) as an attractive therapeutic target for AD. Herein, we report 3-substituted indolin-2-one derivatives as the first isoform-selective JNK3 inhibitors by multistage screening. In this study, comparative structure-based virtual screening was performed, and J30-8 was identified with a half-maximal inhibitory concentration of 40 nM, which exhibited over 2500-fold isoform selectivity and marked kinome-wide selectivity. Further study indicated that 1 μM J30-8 exhibited neuroprotective activity in vitro so as to alleviate the spatial memory impairment in vivo through reducing plaque burden and inhibiting the phosphorylation of JNKs, Aβ precursor protein, and Tau protein. All of these indicated J30-8 as proved isoform-selective JNK3 inhibitors that might serve as a useful tool for further JNK3 studies with AD as well as for the development of JNK3 inhibitors for the potential treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the main form of dementia that has become the fourth leading killer of the elderly after cardiovascular disease and cancer.(1) Clinically, AD is characterized by memory loss, language decline, and other serious disorders of cognitive abilities.(2) According to the World Alzheimer Report in 2018, an estimated 50 million people are living with AD or some form of dementia.(3) To date, although new anti-AD drugs have made some progress, there are only five drugs, including four cholinesterase inhibitors and one N-methyl-d-aspartate receptor antagonist, approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.(4,5) However, clinical studies have shown that these drugs have limited effect in improving the AD-related cognitive deficits and do not delay the progression of disease.(6−8) Recently, Geng and co-workers have reported a marine-derived oligosaccharide, GV-971, which showed statistically marked improvements in the cognition of AD patients in a phase III study at the conference on clinical trials in alzheimer’s disease.(9) Therefore, it is an urgent clinical need to develop novel therapies, delay the progression, and modify the underlying pathophysiology of AD.
    c-Jun N-terminal kinases (JNKs), as serine/threonine kinases, belong to the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) family.(10) The JNKs can be activated by many stimulating factors such as cytokines, growth factors, oxidative stress, or amyloid β (Aβ) -protein peptides, affecting the life process of apoptosis, immune response, and autophagy.(11−13) There are three genes, namely, jnk1, jnk2, and jnk3, encoded for 10 different splice forms of JNK.(14,15) Among them, JNK1 and JNK2 are spliced into four variants (JNK1/2-α1, -α2, -β1, and -β2) and JNK3 is spliced into two variants (JNK3-α1 and -α2).(13) Although JNK1 and JNK2 are ubiquitously expressed, JNK3 is mainly expressed in the brain and to a lesser extent in the heart and the testis.(16) Recent studies have shown that JNK3 is the primary kinase that is responsible for phosphorylating Aβ precursor protein (APP) at the position of Thr668, leading to accelerating the formation of the Aβ product levels and subsequent senile plaques.(17,18) In postmortem cortical tissues, JNK3 is markedly activated in human AD patients and a familial AD mouse model.(19) The deletion of JNK3 results in dramatical decrease of Aβ deposition level.(19) Moreover, JNK3 expression exists in Tau protein polymer and therefore affects the stability of cytoskeleton, leading to apoptosis.(20) JNK3 also directly regulates the formation of neurofibrillary tangle (NFT) by phosphorylating Tau protein, and this pathological change is positively correlated with neuron loss and cognitive impairment.(21) Owing to the selective tissue distribution of JNK3 in the brain, the findings that JNK3 deletion or inhibition exhibited amelioration of neurodegeneration in animal models of AD make JNK3 an attractive therapeutic target for AD.(22−26)
    Currently, a number of pan-JNK inhibitors have been discovered and two molecules are going through clinical trials (Figure 1).(10,27) Even so, there is no JNK inhibitor on the market yet. SP600125 (1) is the first reported pan-JNK inhibitor and can reverse Alzheimer’s disease phenotype in homozygous APPswe/PS1dE9 double-transgenic mice through reducing the formation of senile plaques and neurofibrillary tangle and improving AD-related cognitive deficits.(22,28) Although SP600125 has poor kinase selectivity, it is still a reference compound commonly used in research.(25,29−31)AS-602801 (2) is in phase II study for the treatment of inflammatory endometriosis.(32−34)Tanzisertib (3) is a potent inhibitor of pan-JNK for the treatment of discoid lupus erythematosus and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis but was terminated in phase II clinical trials with no specific reasons reported.(35,36) Compound 4, an aminopyrazole derivative, was reported as an isoform-selective JNK3 inhibitor. Compound 4 exhibited over 50-fold isoform selectivity against JNK1, but the selectivity to JNK2 was not satisfied with only 1.51-fold JNK2/JNK3 isoform selectivity.(37) To the best of our knowledge, most of the known molecules are pan-JNK inhibitors without isoform selectivity, due to the highly conserved adenosine 5′-triphosphate (ATP)-binding sites of the three isoforms.(10,38,39) Due to the lack of isoform-selective JNK3 inhibitors, it is not conducive to the study of the relationship between the progression of AD and the isoforms of JNKs.(40,41) Thus, the discovery of more potent and isoform-selective JNK3 inhibitors contributes to understanding the mechanism and drug discovery of AD.
    Virtual screening (VS) has become an effective tool for lead compounds identification and drug discovery.(42−44) Herein, we report a successful case of comparative structure-based VS, structure–activity relationship (SAR) study driven by similarity screening, and multistage evaluation to discover novel isoform-selective JNK3 inhibitors. Among the identified hits, compound J30-8 with indolin-2-one core exhibited JNK3 with a half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50) value of 40 nM, which shows 2500-fold isoform selectivity against JNK1α1 and JNK2α2 and excellent kinome-wide selectivity against screened 398 kinases. Further pharmacological and mechanism experiments revealed that J30-8 had a marked neuroprotective effect against Aβ25–35-induced cell death in vitro and dramatically alleviated the spatial memory impairment through reducing the accumulation of Aβ and the phosphorylation of Tau protein in vivo. The pharmacokinetic and brain penetration studies indicated that J30-8 exhibited high effective plasma exposure and a certain amount of intracerebral distribution. Finally, the binding modes of these scaffolds were investigated by molecular docking and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations for further structural optimization.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Model Building and Structure-Based Virtual Screening

    As drawn in Figure 2A, more than 40 JNK3 crystal structures have been reported in the Protein Data Bank (PDB, https://www.rcsb.org/). To identify suitable crystal structures for the following structure-based virtual screening, we first constructed an unbiased benchmarking data set specialized for JNK3, containing 21 active ligands (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information) and 1024 decoys generated by “MUBD-DECOYMAKER” previously developed by our group,(45) to evaluate the selected JNK3 crystal structures. Then, the quality of the aforementioned data set was validated by six physicochemical properties, including A log P, molecular weight, number of hydrogen-bond donors, number of hydrogen-bond acceptors, number of rotatable bonds, and net formal charge. The results indicated that the physicochemical properties of the active ligands and decoys maintained a good similarity (Figure 2B), which meant that the unbiased benchmarking data set was able to evaluate the JNK3 crystal structure models.
    As for JNK3 crystal structures, 15 representative JNK3 complexes were selected according to the diversity and activity of the ligands from their corresponding crystal structures (see Table S1 in the Supporting Information) and cross-docking was used to verify the docking reproducibility for the original binding modes of active ligands. The results showed that eight of them (PDB entries: 1PMV, 2P33, 2ZDU, 3CGF, 3FV8, 3TTI, 4W4W, and 4Y46) seemed to provide good overall performance according to the root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) values and docking scores (see Tables S2 and S3 in the Supporting Information). Among them, two crystal structures (PDB entries: 4W4W and 2P33) showed excellent docking reproducibility with the lowest average RMSD value equal to 3.03 Å and the best average docking score value equal to −9.3 kcal/mol. These eight crystal structures were thus applied to screen the aforesaid unbiased benchmarking data set.
    As drawn in Figure 2C, the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves demonstrated that two crystal structures (PDB entries: 3TTI and 4W4W) were basically above others, whose areas under the ROC (AUC) curves were 0.87 and 0.89, respectively (Figure 2D and Table S4). In general, only top 1% ranked results of the virtual screening are retained for further selection; thus, the enrichment efficacy at the level of top 1% is more important for the validation study.(46) As shown in Figure 2D and Table S4, the EF1% values of the crystal structures (PDB entries: 3TTI and 4W4W) were 30 and 25, respectively, which were remarkably better than those of the other six docking complexes. Based on the aforementioned data, two crystal structures (PDB entries: 3TTI and 4W4W) were selected as the initial templates for the following structure-based VS.
    As shown in Figure 2A, approximately 300 000 compounds from SPECS chemical library and Chinese National Compound Library of Peking University (PKU-CNCL) were docked into crystal structures (PDB entries: 4W4W and 2P33) using Glide molecular docking module. The top-ranked 1% results based on scoring, about 3000 compounds each crystal structures, were retained. Then, those interacted with residue Met149, a key residue in the hinge domain for the binding affinity of JNK3, were kept through the PoseFilter module in the Maestro platform. Finally, 600 compounds were clustered into 50 categories based on ECFP_6 fingerprint. Totally 62 predicted candidates were selected with visual inspection and purchased (Table S5).

    Seven Novel JNK3 Inhibitors Were Identified

    A total of 62 compounds were evaluated through radiometric assays, and seven compounds, J14, J24, J29, J30, J46, J48, and J49 (Figure 3A), exhibited over 50% inhibition of JNK3 at the concentration of 10 μM (see Table S5, hit rate = 11.3%). All of the active compounds have passed the pan assay interference compounds (PAINS) test by PAINS-remover.(47) Further IC50 assays indicated that the seven identified compounds exhibited satisfactory enzymatic inhibition, with IC50 values ranging from 0.25 to 14.19 μM (Figures 3B and S2). Among them, three compounds, J29, J30, and J46, had the IC50 values of 0.62, 0.59, and 0.25 μM, respectively. Further isoform-selective assays showed that these three compounds had the JNK1α1 and JNK2α2 IC50 values higher than 100 μM with selectivities of JNK3/JNK1α1 and JNK3/JNK2α2 over 160-fold (Figure 3B), respectively, suggesting these compounds showed excellent selectivity to the other isoforms of JNKs.
    Besides, the representative physicochemical properties of the seven identified JNK3 inhibitors were calculated by Pipeline Pilot 8.5, and the results indicated that these compounds displayed desirable physicochemical properties, except for the A log P of compound J48, just a little over 5.00 (Figure 3B). The results of predicted brain–blood partition coefficient demonstrated that identified inhibitors exhibited satisfactory blood–brain barrier (BBB) permeability with the ADMET_BBB_Level below 3, except for compound J49, outside the confidence area of the regression model.(48) The Tanimoto coefficients of each identified inhibitors to each known JNK3 inhibitor in the CHEMBL database (version 24, https://www.ebi.ac.uk/chembl/) were calculated based on ECFP_6 fingerprints and showed no similarity to any known JNK3 inhibitor with the Tanimoto coefficient below 0.22. All of these indicated that the identified molecules expanded the chemical space of JNK3 inhibitors and provided a good starting point for further chemical modifications, especially the compounds J29, J30, and J46.

    Similarity Searching and Preliminary Structure–Activity Relationships (SARs) Study

    To study the SARs of these new scaffolds and find more potent inhibitors, derivatization modification and synthesis were necessary, but it would cost a lot of time. Fortunately, 22 analogues of compounds J29 and J30 and 15 analogues of compounds J46 were captured in the SPECS chemical library and PKU-CNCL databases through two-dimensional (2D) similarity searching based on the Tanimoto coefficient of ECFP_6 fingerprints.
    As shown in Table 1 (for dose dependency curves, see Figure S3), replacement of the 3-chloro-2-methylphenylamino of J29 with a carbonyl group (J30-1) led to a significant loss of JNK3 inhibition. The replacement of the naphthyl group of J30 with a 3-chloro-2-methylphenyl group (J30-12) slightly improved inhibitory activity. Then, replacement of the 3-chloro-2-methylphenyl group of J29 or the naphthyl group of J30 with a phenyl group (J30-10), p-substituted phenyl groups (J30-2, J30-3, J30-5, J30-6, J30-7, J30-11, J30-13, and J30-16), a phenyl group with electron-withdrawing substitution (J30-15), or a morpholine ring (J30-9) led to a decrease of potency. These results revealed that the phenyl ring of J29 could be modified with small hydrophobic groups substitution, especially halogen replacement, in the ortho/meta-position. The bromine/chlorine/fluorine atom substitution at the C-5 position of the indol-2-one core (J30, J30-8, J30-12, and J30-14) was essential for maintaining or enhancing activity. Among them, the 5-fluorine-substituted compound J30-8, with an IC50 value of 0.04 μM, displayed more than 15-fold improvement of inhibitory potency compared to J29. However, replacement of the 5-bromine atom on the indol-2-one core of J29 with methyl or ethyl group (J30-17, J30-18, and J30-19) led to the loss of potency, suggesting that the C-5 position of the indol-2-one core was suitable for a halogen replacement. The substitutions at the C-7 or N-1 position of the indol-2-one core (J30-20, J30-21, and J30-22) led to a significant loss of activity, indicating that the C-7 or N-1 position of the indol-2-one core could not be substituted. Besides, the predicted brain–blood partition coefficients of 3-substituted indolin-2-one derivatives indicated that most of the compounds have satisfactory blood–brain barrier permeability with the ADMET_BBB_Level below 3, except for compound J30-13.
    Table 1. Enzymatic Activity and Chemical Structures of the 22 Analogues of Compounds J29 and J30
    a

    Data are presented as geometric mean values of at least two independent runs.

    b

    Molecular weight.

    c

    Predicted octanol/water partition coefficient using Pipeline Pilot 8.5.

    d

    Log of brain/blood partition coefficient (Log BB); 0: very high, 1: high, 2: medium, 3: low, 4: undefined.

    e

    Not determined.

    As shown in Table 2 (for dose dependency curves, see Figure S3), replacement of the naphthyl group of J46 with a smaller aromatic ring, including a phenyl group (J46-1), para-substituted phenyl group (J46-2 and J46-3), furan ring (J46-4), and thiophene ring (J46-5) led to a significant loss of JNK3 inhibition. We proposed that smaller substituents would reduce the hydrophobic interaction formed by the naphthyl group of J46. Thus, the naphthyl group was important for JNK3 inhibitory activity. Furthermore, replacement of the nitrogen atom to oxygen atom in the lactam of the quinoxaline core (J46-6–10) did not improve the inhibitory activity, which meant that the NH in the lactam might provide hydrogen-bond donor comparing with the oxygen atom. In addition, substitutions at the C-6 or C-7 position of the quinoxaline core (J46-11–15) led to a decrease of potency. Furthermore, three active compounds, J46, J46-1, and J46-2, showed satisfactory blood–brain barrier permeability with the ADMET_BBB_Level below 3.

    Isoform and Kinome-Wide Selectivity Study

    To verify the isoform selectivity and kinome-wide selectivity of the identified JNK3 inhibitors, compounds J30-8 and J46 were synthesized (Figure 4A).(49,50) The structures of J30-8 and J46 were characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) experiments as single substances. The double bond of J46 has cis–trans isomerism and the cis structure can form an intramolecular hydrogen bond with low-energy and stable structure.(49) The following isoform selectivity assays indicated that compound J30-8 showed no inhibition against JNK1α1 and JNK2α2 (IC50 > 100 μM) (Figure 4B) and showed higher than 2500-fold isoform selectivity against JNK1α1 and JNK2α2 (Figure 4D). Additionally, compound J46 exhibited no inhibition to JNK1α1 at 100 μM and 40% inhibition to JNK2α2 at 30 μM, which meant that there were some differences between the scaffolds of J30-8 and J46 in the isoform selectivity of JNK2α2. Further kinases panel selectivity study revealed that compound J30-8 only inhibited Abl (h), Abl (Q252H) (h), Abl (Y253F) (h), and Yes (h) with the IC50 values of 13.93, 8.00, 10.99, and 7.70 μM, respectively. At the same time, compound J46 inhibited DDR1 (h), EGFR (L858R) (h), and EGFR (T790M, L858R) (h) with the IC50 values of 0.16, 4.50, and 0.37 μM (Figure 4C,D and Table S6), respectively. To sum up, the two promising JNK3 inhibitors, J30-8 and J46, demonstrated excellent isoform selectivity and kinome-wide selectivity and deserved further optimization study. In addition, J30-8 had better isoform selectivity and kinome-wide selectivity than J46.

    Compound J30-8 Treatment Demonstrated Marked Neuroprotection Effect in Vitro

    Three compounds J30-8, J30-12, and J46, with good JNK3 inhibitory activities, were further evaluated for their neuroprotection activity against Aβ25–35-induced cellular toxicity in SH-SY5Y cells. LiCl, a potential therapeutic drug for AD, was tested as a reference.(51) The results showed that Aβ25–35 induced 20–30% SH-SY5Y cell death at the concentration of 20 μM (Figure 5A, p < 0.01) and 10 mM LiCl exhibited efficient neuroprotective activity on SH-SY5Y cells (p < 0.05). For indol-2-one scaffold, 10 μM compound J30-8 showed comparable neuroprotective activity with 10 mM LiCl, and 1 μM J30-8 also showed considerable neuroprotective activity (p < 0.05). For quinoxaline scaffold, compound J46 did not have neuroprotective activity at the concentration of 10 or 1 μM, which might be related to the physicochemical properties and the cellular membrane permeability of compound J46. Besides, compounds J30-8 and J46 had no effect on SH-SY5Y cells proliferation and LiCl could promote cell proliferation at the testing concentrations (Figure 5B).

    Compound J30-8 Treatment Could Improve Learning and Memory Abilities in APPswe/PS1dE9 Mice

    Encouraged by the excellent neuroprotective activity of compound J30-8 in vitro, we set out to test the behavioral effects of J30-8 in homozygous APPswe/PS1dE9 double-transgenic mice model. SP600125, reportedly reversing AD phenotypes to normal level in vivo, was selected as the positive control.(22) As indicated in Figure 6A, no significant differences in the body weights were observed among four groups of mice. Moreover, J30-8 or SP600125 treatment significantly alleviated the spatial learning impairment, for shorter escape latency and traveled distance in the positioning navigation experiments (Figure 6B,C), and also longer time spent in the target quadrant during the probe trial (Figure 6D,E) compared to the vehicle-treated mice (p < 0.01). Besides, the time spent in the target quadrant of J30-8 (30 mg/kg) group was significantly longer than that in the SP600125 (30 mg/kg) group (p < 0.01) in the probe trials. Further visual platform trails indicated that there was no significant difference in the swimming speed and the time to reach the target among the four groups of mice (Figure 6F,G), suggesting that the differences in the behavioral parameters were mainly attributable to differences in learning and memory abilities of the mice. In the step-through passive avoidance tasks (Figure 6H), there was no significant difference in the latency of each group in the acquisition phase, while in the memory retention test phase (Figure 6I), the retention latencies of SP600125 and J30-8 treatment were significantly higher than that of the vehicle-treated group (p < 0.01). Besides, the J30-8 (30 mg/kg) group had a significantly longer retention latency than the SP600125 (30 mg/kg) group (p < 0.01). Collectively, the behavioral indexes of mice in the J30-8 groups and the SP600125 groups were significantly improved compared to those of the vehicle-treated group, and the effect of J30-8 (30 mg/kg) group was better than that of the SP600125 (30 mg/kg) group.

    Compound J30-8 Treatment Reduced the Diffuse and Fibrillar Aβ Plaques in the Cortex and Hippocampus

    Aimed to reveal the mechanism of behavioral improvement, the brain Aβ deposition was analyzed by immunofluorescence assays. The results showed that the number of diffuse and fibrillar plaques as well as the percentage of area occupied by diffuse and fibrillar plaques in the cortex (Figure 7A,B, p < 0.01) and hippocampus (Figure 7C,D, p < 0.05) markedly decreased in the SP600125- and J30-8-treated mice compared to the vehicle-treated mice. Besides, the inhibitory effect of the J30-8 (30 mg/kg) group was rather better than that of the SP600125 (30 mg/kg) group in diffuse plaques (p < 0.05) and fibrillar plaques (p < 0.05). Thus, our findings demonstrated that compound J30-8 can dose-dependently reduce the number of diffuse and fibrillar Aβ plaques and the proportion of plaques in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, and the inhibitory effect of J30-8 (30 mg/kg) was better than that of SP600125 (30 mg/kg), which was consistent with the JNK3 inhibitory activity and the aforementioned phenotype results.

    Compound J30-8 Treatment Inhibited the Phosphorylation of JNK, APP, and Tau Protein in the Cortex and Hippocampus

    The western blotting assays were used to verify whether the aforesaid phenotype and mechanism were caused by the inhibition of JNK3, APP, and Tau protein phosphorylation (Figure 8A,B). The results indicated that the phosphorylation levels of JNK, APP (Thr668), Tau (Ser235), and Tau (Thr205) in the cortex and hippocampus were dramatically decreased in the SP600125 (30 mg/kg) and J30-8 (30 mg/kg) groups compared to those in the vehicle-treated group (see Figure 8C–F, p < 0.001, respectively). Besides, compared to SP600125 (30 mg/kg) treatment, J30-8 (30 mg/kg) treatment significantly downregulated the phosphorylation levels of JNKs (hippocampus, p < 0.01), APP (Thr668) (p < 0.01), Tau (Ser235) (hippocampus, p < 0.01), and Tau (Thr205) (cortex, p < 0.001; hippocampus, p < 0.01). Furthermore, the expressions of sAPPα, a metabolite of α-secretase, were markedly increased (p < 0.001) (Figure 8G), and the expressions of sAPPβ, a metabolite of β-secretase, were significantly decreased (p < 0.001) after treated with J30-8 and SP600125, and J30-8 could more effectively transform sAPPβ to sAPPα than SP600125 at the same dose (Figure 8H). To sum up, specific inhibition of JNK activation by J30-8 treatment could reduce the phosphorylation levels of APP and Tau protein and transform sAPPβ to sAPPα, leading to effectively rescue cognitive impairments.

    Pharmacokinetic and Brain Penetration Study of J30-8 and SP600125 in the Appswe/PS1dE9 Mice

    To determine the pharmacokinetic profiles of J30-8 and SP600125, these compounds were intravenously (i.v.) and intraperitoneally (i.p.) injected into the APPswe/PS1dE9 mice with single and multiple doses, respectively. The results indicated that the pharmacokinetic behaviors of J30-8 and SP600125 for the i.v. (3 mg/kg) and i.p. (30 mg/kg) administration conformed to the two-compartment model (Figures 9 and S4). As shown in Table 3, J30-8 and SP600125 showed similar mean retention times (MRTs) in the administration doses of 3 mg/kg (i.v.). Furthermore, J30-8 was rapidly distributed (t1/2(α) = 0.34 h) and slowly eliminated (t1/2(β) = 16.11 h) in the administration dose of 30 mg/kg (i.p.), while SP600125 was rapidly distributed (t1/2(α) = 0.21 h) and eliminated (t1/2(β) = 1.23 h) in vivo. Notably, the plasma concentrations of J30-8 and SP600125 at 24 h after i.p. (30 mg/kg) administrations were 41 and 22 ng/mL, respectively (Figure 9), which were higher than the IC50 values of JNK3 for two compounds (J30-8 is 15 ng/mL and SP600125 is 20 ng/mL). It was consistent with the results of the pharmacodynamic experiment and might result in the better pharmacology efficacy of J30-8 than SP600125 in the administration doses of 30 mg/kg (i.p.). Besides, both compounds had high effective plasma exposure with high maximum concentrations (Cmax) and areas under the curve (AUC) in the administration doses of 3 mg/kg (i.v.) and 30 mg/kg (i.p.), respectively. The clearance of SP600125 was similar to that of J30 and both in an acceptable range. Two compounds also showed good bioavailability, and J30-8 (F = 90.53%) showed higher bioavailability than SP600125 (F = 81.53%). Additionally, there was no obvious accumulation after multiple-dose administration of J30-8 and SP600125 (Table S7).

    Binding Modes and Isoform Selectivity Analysis

    To explain the SARs of two new chemical scaffolds, two representative compounds J30-8 and J46 were docked into the ATP-binding site of JNK3 (PBD entries: 4WHZ and 4W4W).(37,52) As shown in Figure 10A, the indolin-2-one moiety of J30-8 was located at the hinge region of JNK3 and its hydrogen atom of NH and oxygen atom of carbonyl formed two hydrogen bonds to the backbone carbonyl and NH of Met149, suggesting that the lactam in indol-2-one played a key role in achieving promising inhibitory activity against JNK3. Besides, the thiazol-4-one scaffold had a hydrophobic interaction with Val78, Ala91, Met146, Val196, and Leu206, and the 2-chlorophenyl group of J30-8 was deeply buried in the hydrophobic region I (HR I) formed by Ala91, Ile92, Lys93, Ile124, Leu126, Leu144, Val145, Met146, and Leu206 (Figure S5A). In addition, the 4-position of the 2-chlorophenyl group was close to the Leu144 of JNK3 with a distance of 3.9 Å between two carbon atoms and could not be substituted by any group. The binding mode of compound J46 (Figure 10B) was similar to that of J30-8, and the lactam in the quinoxaline core of J46 interacted with the JNK3 hinge region via two hydrogen bonds with Met149. There was also an intramolecular hydrogen bond and the HR I was occupied by naphthyl group in J46 (Figure S5B), and any group substitution in the 4-position of naphthyl group would clash with Leu144, leading to the decrease of inhibition. To summarize, these findings well consist of the results of the aforesaid SARs study, and the occupation of HR I pocket was of great necessity.
    To investigate the high selectivities of compounds J30-8 and J46 to the other isoforms of JNK, the JNK1 (PDB entry: 3PZE) and JNK2 (PDB entry: 3E7O) crystal structures were superimposed to the crystal structure of JNK3.(53,54) As drawn in Figure 10C,D, the methylthio group of Met108 of JNK1 or JNK2 was located at the center of HR I pocket and had a collision with the 2-chlorophenyl group of J30-8 and the naphthyl group of J46, which led to the loss of inhibitory activity to JNK1α1 and JNK2α2. Notably, the HR I pocket was also called selectivity pocket for achieving the selectivity to other kinases in the MAPK family.(37) Our findings first demonstrate that the occupation of HR I pocket can achieve isoform selectivity for JNK3 against two other isoforms.
    Aimed to explain the marked kinome-wide selectivity of J30-8, we compared the binding modes of J30-8 and sunitinib, a multitarget kinase inhibitor with oxindole structure.(55) As drawn in Figure 11A,B, the hydrogen bonds were flipped in the hinge region between the binding modes of J30-8 in JNK3 (PDB entry: 4WHZ) and sunitinib in vascular endothelial growth factor receptor (VEGFR) (PDB entry: 4AGD),(37,55) which led to the 2-chlorophenyl group of J30-8 deeply buried in the HR I. For sunitinib was a multitarget kinase inhibitor, we proposed that the reverse of the binding modes of oxindole might make the marked kinome-wide selectivity of J30-8.
    To verify the binding modes of J30-8 and J46 in a dynamic condition, 50 ns MD simulations were performed with Desmond software.(56) Both of the complexes were stable after 30 ns simulations (Figure S6), and then the last 20 ns trajectories were extracted and analyzed. The results of MD were well consistent with the docking results and the binding patterns of two compounds did not change. For compound J30-8 (Figure 12A,C), two hydrogen bonds formed by the lactam and the hinge region Met149 existed during 99 and 67% of the simulation time, respectively, indicating that the lactam of indolin-2-one could be modified to form more stable hydrogen-bond interaction, especially the carbonyl group. The hydrophilic side of thiazol-4-one formed three hydrogen bonds with Gln75 and Asn152 and a water bridge with Lys93 occupying 80, 18, 29, and 14% of the simulation time, indicating that the interactions of the hydrophilic side were weak and unstable. The 2-chlorophenyl group was well embedded in the HR I pocket and provided selectivity to other isoforms of JNK. For compound J46 (Figure 12B,D), the quinoxaline formed two hydrogen bonds with the Met149 over 95% of the simulation time, suggesting that the quinoxaline was a good chemical scaffold for JNK3 inhibitors. Interestingly, the naphthyl group formed π-cation interaction with the Lys93 during 57% of the simulation time, which could explain the fact that the replacement of the naphthyl group led to a significant loss of JNK3 inhibitory activity. Overall, these findings guide us to well understand the SARs of these new scaffolds and seek more optimal JNK3 inhibitors in the future.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In the current work, we constructed an unbiased benchmarking data set for JNK3 and discovered two suitable crystal complexes for structure-based VS. Then, several new scaffold inhibitors of JNK3 were identified, and three compounds, J29, J30, and J46, showed JNK3 IC50 values at the nanomolar level. Further optimization based on the structural scaffolds of these compounds led to the discovery of compound J30-8 with the JNK3 IC50 value of 40 nM, exhibiting over 2500-fold isoform selectivity against the JNK1α1 and JNK2α2 and excellent kinome-wide selectivity against screened 398 kinases. Besides, compound J30-8 showed comparable neuroprotective activity with LiCl in vitro and dramatically improved learning and memory abilities in the APPswe/PS1dE9 mice. Further mechanism study indicated that J30-8 could markedly reduce the diffuse and fibrillar Aβ plaques through inhibiting the phosphorylation of JNK, APP, and Tau protein in the cortex and hippocampus. The pharmacokinetic brain penetration studies showed that J30-8 exhibited high effective plasma exposure and a certain amount of intracerebral distribution, and it was consistent with the pharmacodynamic results. Therefore, J30-8, as the first proved isoform-selective JNK3 inhibitor with neuroprotective activity in vitro and anti-AD efficacy in vivo, might serve as a useful tool for further JNK3 studies with AD and also the development of JNK3 inhibitors for the potential treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Construction of Unbiased Benchmarking Data Set

    The unbiased benchmarking data set used to evaluate the performance of structure-based VS was constructed through “MUBD-DECOYMAKER” previously developed by our research group.(45) MUBD-DECOYMAKER is a ligand filter and decoy generation tool, and it can ensure the diversity of ligands and maintain the physicochemical properties similar and chemical topology dissimilar between ligands and decoys, providing unbiased test sets for the model validation in virtual screening. According to the protocol, including (1) analogues excluding strategy, (2) physicochemical properties-based filtering strategy, and (3) topology-based filtering strategy, 91 active ligands were collected from the ChEMBL database and literature with the JNK3 IC50 value lower than 10 nM first.(57) Then, analogues were excluded, reducing the amount of selected active ligands to 21 (Figure S1). Following, 474 inactive ligands were gathered from the ChEMBL database and literature with the JNK3 IC50 value higher than 10 000 nM, and 205 inactive ligands were retained after the same process. For each selected active ligands, 39 decoys were selected from the ZINC database (http://www.zinc.org/)(58) after the filter process of MUBD-DECOYMAKER, ensuring the similarity of six physiochemical properties (molecular weight, formal charge, hydrogen-bond donors/acceptors, rotatable bonds, and AlogP) but structural dissimilarity (Tanimoto coefficient < 0.75). Finally, the unbiased benchmarking data set specialized for JNK3 inhibitors was constituted by 21 active ligands and 1024 decoys.

    Preparation of Ligands and Crystal Structures

    All of the chemicals in unbiased benchmarking data set and screening databases were processed using the LigPrep module in Schrödinger 10.2 software (Schrödinger, LLC, NY).(59) Epik module in Schrödinger(60) was used to generate the ionized states and tautomers/stereoisomers at pH = 7.0 ± 2.0. The original chiralities were preserved for JNK3 inhibitors with known three-dimensional (3D) structures, and different combinations of chiralities were generated for the decoys without 3D structures. The maximum number of stereoisomers for each decoy was set to 32 and the low-energy ring conformation was set to 1. The OPLS3 force field was adopted to perform energy minimization.
    The crystallographic structures of the JNK3 in complex with inhibitors were retrieved from the RCSB Protein Data Bank (PDB), and crystal structures with incomplete ATP binding site were removed, such as incomplete G-loop. Then, a total of 28 JNK3 crystal structures, including PDB IDs 1JNK, 1PMN, 1PMU, 1PMV, 2O0U, 2P33, 2R9S, 2ZDT, 2ZDU, 3CGF, 3CGO, 3FV8, 3KVX, 3OXI, 3PTG, 3TTI, 3TTJ, 4KKE, 4KKH, 4W4V, 4W4W, 4W4X, 4W4Y, 4WHZ, 4X21, 4Y5H, 4Y46, and 4Z9L, were prepared by the Protein Preparation Wizard module. Proteins were assigned bond orders, added hydrogens, protonated, removed all crystallographic water molecules, and restrained minimization until the root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) lower than 0.3 Å based on the OPLS3 force field.

    Structure-Based Virtual Screening

    The above-mentioned 28 crystal structures of human JNK3 were grouped into 12 categories according to the similarity of ligands (Table S1). Then, 12 representative crystal structures were selected from the corresponding category based on the activity and diversity of the ligands, which were further subjected to cross-docking using Xglide from the Schrödinger script center.(61) For each selected JNK3 crystal structure, the ligand was extracted from the complex and then docked into the ATP-binding sites of 12 crystal structures. The binding pockets with the size of 10 Å × 10 Å × 10 Å were defined for each JNK3 complex and centered at the centroid of associated co-crystallized ligands. The “extra precision (XP)” was ticked and all of the remaining parameters for Xglide were kept as default values. Next, eight JNK3 complexes with better RMSD and docking score were used to screen the unbiased benchmarking data set specialized for JNK3 inhibitors. The performances of the eight JNK3 complexes to enrich active compounds were evaluated and compared using enrichment factors study, which was a small retrospective study conducted to investigate the ability of docking model to distinguish between active ligands and inactive compounds (decoys). The receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves were prepared by plotting the true-positive rate against the false-positive rate, and the corresponding area under the curve (AUC) values were calculated. The enrichment factors (EFs) were computed according to eq 1(1)where (Nexperimental) is the number of experimentally found active structures in the top x% of the sorted test set and (Nactive) is the total number of active structures in the test set.
    Approximately 300 000 compounds from the SPECS chemical library and PKU-CNCL database were docked into two JNK3 crystal structures (3TTI and 4W4W), and three predicted binding poses were generated for each compound. Then, top-ranked 3000 compounds scored by the XP scoring function of Glide were retained and 1526 compounds appeared in the docking result of two JNK3 crystal structures were selected for binding pose filter to ensure at least one hydrogen bond with residue Met149. The remaining compounds were structurally clustered into 50 clusters based on the Tanimoto coefficients computed using the ECFP_6 fingerprint. Then, one or two compounds were chosen in each cluster according to the docking score and the diversity of structure. Finally, 62 candidates were purchased and evaluated using a radiometric protein kinase assay.

    Similarity Search

    Pipeline Pilot 8.5 of Accelrys was used to perform all of the similarity searches.(56) The fingerprint ECFP_6 was generated for each structure, and similarities were calculated using the Tanimoto coefficient. Then, 22 analogues of compounds J29 and J30 and 15 analogues of compounds J46 were identified and purchased for biological evaluation.

    Molecular Dynamics Simulations

    Following molecular docking, independent 50 ns MD simulations were performed for compounds J30-8 and J46 ligand–protein complex using the Desmond software.(56) Na+ and Cl– ions were added at the physiological concentration of 0.15 M to ensure the overall neutrality of the systems. Simulations were conducted with an OPLS3 force field and a TIP3P explicit solvent model. The final size of the solvated system was close to ∼50 000 atoms. We chose a 4.8 ps recording interval, and the NPT ensemble was employed with temperature fixed at 300 K and pressure at 1.01 bar. The integration time step was set at 2 fs. The model systems were relaxed using a six-step default protocol implemented in Desmond and utilized to prepare systems for production quality simulation. Default settings were used for all other parameters. The simulation interaction diagram analysis tool was used to monitor energetics, RMSD fluctuations, hydrogen-bond distances, angles, and van der Waals interactions over the simulation trajectories.

    Compound Synthesis and Characterization

    The screened compounds were purchased from SPECS database (http://www.specs.net) or PKU-CNCL (http://www.pkucncl.com/). The purities of all purchased and synthesized compounds are more than 95% by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). For the chemical synthesis study, synthesis reagents and solvents were obtained from J&K Chemical (Beijing, China) and used without further purification. Characterizations of compounds J30-8 and J46 are provided in the Supporting Information. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker (400 MHz) instruments, using dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-d6 as solvents. High-resolution mass spectra were recorded on a Bruker Apex IV FTMS mass spectrometer using electrospray ionization (ESI).

    General Procedures for Preparation of J30-8(50)

    A solution of 1-(2-chlorophenyl)thiourea (10.0 mmol, 1.86 g), chloroacetic acid (10.0 mmol, 945 mg), 5-fluoroindoline-2,3-dione (10.0 mmol, 1.65 g), and sodium acetate (10.0 mmol, 820 mg) in acetic acid (100 mL) was stirred under reflux for 4 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the reddish brown precipitate was filtered off. The residue was washed with acetic acid (20 mL), water (20 mL), ethanol (20 mL), and diethyl ether (20 mL) in sequence and then recrystallized from a mixture solvent of dimethylformamide (DMF)/ethanol (20:1).

    2-((2-Chlorophenyl)imino)-5-((Z)-5-fluoro-2-oxoindolin-3-ylidene)thiazolidin-4-one (J30-8)

    Reddish brown solid. Yield: 68%. mp > 380 °C (decomposed). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 13.02 (s, 1H), 11.19 (s, 1H), 8.62 (d, J = 12.3 Hz, 1H), 7.57 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.39 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 7.23 (td, J = 8.8, 2.6 Hz, 2H), 7.15 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 1H), 6.92 (dd, J = 8.5, 4.6 Hz, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 168.8, 159.1, 156.7, 140.0, 134.6, 130.5, 128.6, 126.7, 126.1, 124.7 (d, J = 3.1 Hz, 1C), 123.1, 121.2 (d, J = 10.4 Hz, 1C), 118.5 (d, J = 24.3 Hz, 1C), 115.0 (d, J = 27.7 Hz, 1C), 111.4 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 1C). 19F NMR (376 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ −121.30. HRMS (ESI) [M + H] + calcd for C17H10N3O2FSCl: 374.0166; found: 374.0163.

    General Procedures for Preparation of J46(49)

    Sodium (17.4 mmol, 400 mg) was added to a solution of ethanol (100 mL) in portions and the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The newly prepared sodium ethanol/ethanol solution was obtained. A mixture solvent of α-naphthalene ethyl ketone (10 mmol, 1.70 g) and oxalic acid diethyl ester (15 mmol, 2.19 g) was dropwise added to the aforesaid sodium ethanol/ethanol solution at 0 °C and stirred for another 4 h at room temperature. Then, the mixture was poured into ice water and the pH value was adjusted to 2.0 with hydrochloric acid (2 M). The obtained solid was filtered and washed with water (10 mL), and the crude product ethyl 4-(naphthalen-1-yl)-2,4-dioxobutanoate was used for the next step without purification. A solution of the former crude product (2.0 mmol, 540 mg) and o-phenylenediamine (2 mmol, 216 mg) in ethanol (10 mL) was stirred for 4 h at room temperature. The yellow solid was filtered, and the filter cake was washed with ethanol (10 mL) and water (10 mL) in sequence and then recrystallized from a mixture solvent of DMF/ethanol (15:1).

    (Z)-3-(2-(Naphthalen-1-yl)-2-oxoethylidene)-3,4-dihydroquinoxalin-2(1H)-one (J46)

    Yellow solid. Yield: 26%. mp 251–252 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 13.57 (s, 1H), 12.07 (s, 1H), 8.60–8.46 (m, 1H), 8.07 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 1H), 8.04–7.95 (m, 1H), 7.84 (d, J = 6.8 Hz, 1H), 7.67–7.52 (m, 4H), 7.25–7.09 (m, 3H), 6.58 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 193.6, 156.1, 145.6, 138.7, 133.9, 131.3, 130.0, 128.9, 127.4, 127.2, 126.8, 126.7, 126.0, 125.6, 124.5, 124.5, 124.2, 117.1, 115.9, 94.2. HRMS (ESI) [M + H] + calcd for C20H15N2O2: 315.1134; found: 315.1134.

    Reagents and Cell Culture

    Reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich unless otherwise noted. SP600125 was purchased from Selleck Chemicals LLC. The human neuroblastoma cell line SH-SY5Y was donated by Peking University School of Basic Medical Sciences and cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium containing 15% fetal bovine serum and 100 U/mL penicillin/streptomycin and maintained in a humidified atmosphere of 95% air and 5% CO2.

    Enzymatic Inhibition Assays

    The inhibition activities against JNK3 and 398 screened kinases were tested by Eurofins using KinaseProfiler Service Assay (details are available at https://www.eurofins.com/).(62) JNK3 (h) (JNK1α1 (h) or JNK2α2 (h)) was incubated with 50 mM Tris pH 7.5, 0.1 mM ethylene glycol-bis(β-aminoethyl ether)-N,N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid, 0.1% β-mercaptoethanol, 250 μM peptide (3 μM ATF2), 10 mM MgAcetate, and [γ-33P-ATP] (specific activity approximately 500 cpm/pmol, concentration as required). The reaction was initiated by the addition of the MgATP mix. After incubation for 40 min at room temperature, the reaction was terminated by the addition of 3% phosphoric acid solution. The reaction mixture (10 μL) was then spotted onto a P30 filter mat and washed three times for 5 min in 75 mM phosphoric acid and once in methanol prior to drying and scintillation counting. The activity was defined as the percentage of tested kinase activity in the absence of inhibitor, which was designated as 100%. The IC50 values were determined as the concentration in which 50% inhibition is achieved from the Hill equation fitting.

    Neuroprotection Assays

    The neuroprotection activity against amyloid β (Aβ)-induced toxicity of potential JNK3 inhibitors were determined in SH-SY5Y cells.(63) Aβ25–35 (Aladdin, Shanghai, China) was previously dissolved in water to obtain a 1 mM stock solution and then incubated at 37 °C for 7 days for aging. The cells were seeded at a density of 1 × 104 per well in 96-well plates and cultured for 24 h. Then, the cells were treated with or without compounds (dissolved in DMSO) at the indicated concentrations; 1 h after addition of compounds, 20 μM Aβ25–35 was introduced into each well. After 72 h of Aβ25–35 treatment, 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide assay was performed to examine cell viability, and the absorbance was measured at 570 nm.(37)

    Animal and Treatments

    Animal procedures were according to the University Policies on the Use and Care of Animals. Homozygous APPswe/PS1dE9 double-transgenic mice were purchased from Beijing Vital River Laboratory Animal Technology Co., Ltd. (Beijing, China). Nine month old female mice were randomized into four groups (n = 8, each group), including three treatment groups, intraperitoneally injected J30-8 or SP600125 dissolved in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) containing 2% DMSO at indicated doses once per day for 12 weeks, and one model group received an equal volume of 2% DMSO in PBS as control. During the study, all animals were exposed to pathogen-free, 12 h light/dark cycle environment, sufficient food and water were provided, and bedding was changed at least twice a week. The changes in body weight, activity, adverse drug reaction, and external stimulus were measured and observed weekly.

    Behavioral Tests

    After 12 weeks of treatment, Morris water maze and passive avoidance test were used to evaluate the behavioral tests as reported previously.(22)

    Morris Water Maze

    Briefly, the pool was divided into four quadrants on average according to the four directions of southeast and northwest. For the acquisition training trials, the transparent platform was kept in the same target quadrant and 1.0 cm below the water surface. In each trial, the mice were monitored 90 s after entering the water. If the mice found the platform within 90 s and stayed on the platform for 20 s, it was judged as a successful platform search and the process was recorded as an escape latency period. If a mouse failed to find the platform within 90 s, the escape latency period was recorded as 90 s and the mouse was guided to the platform and allowed to stay on the platform for 20 s. Each mouse was trained once in each quadrant a day for 6 days. For testing the spatial memory, a space exploration experiment was performed after the completion of the last training trail with an interval of 24 h. The mice entered the water from different quadrants and swam freely for 60 s in the pool without an underwater platform for four times. The time ratio of the mice in the quadrant of the original platform was recorded to determine the spatial memory ability of the mice in each experimental group. For visual platform experiment, after the space exploration experiment was completed for 24 h, the platform was placed in the diagonal position of the original hidden platform, 1.0 cm above the water, and other experimental conditions remained unchanged. The mice were put into the pool from four quadrants, and the time and swimming speed required for the mice to reach the visual platform were recorded.

    Passive Avoidance Test

    Briefly, the ENV-010MC shuttle box (Med Associates, Inc. Florida) consisted of one dark compartment and one light compartment, separated by a guillotine door. The stimulator device was connected with the stainless steel fence at the bottom of the dark box side. For the acquisition trial, each mouse was put into the lighted chamber, the guillotine door was opened after 60 s adaptation, and the time of each mouse entering the dark chamber from the light chamber was recorded as acquisition latency. After the mice entered the dark chamber, the gate was closed and a constant foot electric shock (0.3 mA) was given for 3 s. The mice were allowed to stay in the dark chamber for 5 s and then put back into the cage. For testing the retention memory, after 24 h of acquisition trial, the retention latency time was measured according to the aforementioned method without electric shocks. The time when each mouse entered the dark chamber was recorded as the retention latency. If the mice did not enter the dark box after 300 s, it was recorded as 300 s.

    Brain Tissue Preparation

    After behavioral tests, all mice were deeply anesthetized with 10% chloral hydrate anesthesia (100 mg/kg, intraperitoneal injection) and cardiac perfusion was performed with precooled 0.9% normal saline (100 mL). After perfusion, the brain was divided into two hemispheres along the median sagittal suture. One hemisphere tissue was fixed by 4% paraformaldehyde for 12 h, paraffin embedding, and used for immunohistochemical analyses. The other hemisphere tissue was separated to hippocampus and cortex on the ice and then stored at −80 °C for biochemical analyses.

    Immunohistochemical Analyses

    Paraffin section (4 μm thickness) was dewaxed with xylene and dehydrated with gradient alcohol. Antigen retrieval was performed by proteinase K (0.2 mg/mL) treatment, and endogenous peroxidase was inactivated by incubating with 3% H2O2. Nonspecific binding was blocked by incubating with normal goat serum at room temperature for 15 min. The sections were incubated with mouse monoclonal anti-Ab antibody (DE2) overnight at 4 °C for recognizing residues human Aβ1–16 (1:200; Shanghai Haling Biological Technology Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China). Horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-conjugated secondary antibodies were added to detect the primary antibody, and it was visualized by a stable diaminobenzidine solution (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA). The fibrillar Aβ plaques were stained by 1% Thioflavin S (Sigma-Aldrich) and then rinsed by ethanol and distilled water. Fluorescence microscopy was used to capture the green fluorescent fibrillar plaques. Images were observed using an Olympus (Tokyo, Japan) digital microscope. The plaques (total plaques, Aβ1–16-positive plaques, and fibrillar-positive plaques) were calculated by Image-Pro Plus imaging software (Media Cybernetics, Bethesda, MD) in square micrometers.

    Western Blot Analyses

    The western blot assays of hippocampus and cortex were previously reported.(64) Briefly, tissues were homogenized and prepared using radioimmunoprecipitation assay buffer lysis buffer and total protein concentration was determined according to the protocol of the Pierce bicinchoninic acid assay. The polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and poly(vinylidene difluoride) membranes were performed to separate and transfer the equal amounts of protein, respectively. The membranes were blocked by Tris-buffered saline with Tween (TBST) solution containing 5% skim milk and incubated at 4 °C overnight with the primary antibodies, including mouse anti-JNK antibody (1:500; Abcam, Cambridge, U.K.), rabbit anti-p-JNK antibody (1:1000, Abcam, Cambridge, U.K.), mouse anti-APP antibody (1:500, Covance, Princeton, New Jersey), rabbit anti-phosphorylated APP (p-APP; Thr668) antibody (1:500, Abcam, Cambridge, U.K.), mouse antihuman sAPPa (2B3) antibody (1:100, Immuno-Biological Laboratories, Germany), mouse antihuman sAPPb (6A1) antibody (1:100, Immuno-Biological Laboratories, Germany), rabbit anti-Tau antibody (1:500, Abcam, Cambridge, U.K.), rabbit anti-p-Tau (Ser235) antibody (1:500, Abcam, Cambridge, U.K.), rabbit anti-p-Tau (Thr205) antibody (1:500, Abcam, Cambridge, U.K.), and mouse anti-β-actin antibody (1:5000, Abcam, Cambridge, U.K.). The membranes were washed with TBST three times and incubated with goat anti-rabbit IgG (H + L) HRP-labeled secondary antibody (Earthox) for 1 h at room temperature. The blots were detected by ECL Detection Reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Pittsburgh) and ChemiDoc XRS System (Bio-Rad, California).

    Pharmacokinetics Study in Appswe/PS1dE9 Mice

    The HPLC conditions were as follows: column, YMC-Triart C18 (150 mm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm, 120 A); mobile phase, 0.1% FA in water/acetonitrile (Merck Company, Germany) (v/v, 0–3.0 min, 10:90; 3.0–8.0 min, 90:10); flow rate, 0.3 mL/min; column temperature, 40 °C. UV detection, 254 nm. Appswe/PS1dE9 mice (n = 6/group) were dosed with J30-8 or SP600125 via the tail vein for i.v. administration (3 mg/kg, 2% DMSO in saline) or i.p. administration (30 mg/kg, 2% DMSO in saline). After the last administration, 50 μL of orbital blood collection was extracted at 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, and 24 h. After separated by centrifugation, the sample was prepared for high-pressure liquid chromatography/tandem mass spectrometry (LC–MS/MS) analysis by protein precipitation with acetonitrile (500 ng/mL). The characteristic reaction monitoring transitions were m/z 372 → 220 (negative) for J30-8 and m/z 221 → 165 (positive) for SP600125. The pharmacokinetic parameters were calculated through a noncompartmental approach in WinNonlin software v6.3 (Pharsight Corporation, Mountain View).

    Pharmacokinetics Study in Plasma and Brain

    Appswe/PS1dE9 mice (n = 3/group) were dosed with J30-8 or SP600125 via i.p. administration (30 mg/kg, 2% DMSO in saline). At 0.5, 2, and 8 h after administration, the mice were executed and blood samples and brain tissues were collected. The plasma concentrations of the indicated compounds were analyzed through the aforementioned methods. Brain tissue (20 mg) was ground with ultrapure water (200 μL), then homogenate (50 μL) was mixed with 200 μL of 500 ng/mL ISTD, vortexed for 3 min, and centrifuged at 18 000 rpm for 5 min. The supernatant (200 μL) was collected and centrifuged at 18 000 rpm for 5 min. The supernatant was collected and analyzed by HPLC–MS/MS.

    Statistical Analysis

    The data are presented as the mean ± standard deviation of the mean unless otherwise noted. The group differences in the behavioral test were analyzed by one-way analysis of variance, followed by post hoc least significant difference test for multiple comparisons. All other data were analyzed with the Student t-test. All statistical analyses were performed by GraphPad 7.0 software (GraphPad, San Diego, CA). Statistical significance was set at p < 0.05.

      Alzheimer's disease
      Scheltens, Philip; Blennow, Kaj; Breteler, Monique M. B.; de Strooper, Bart; Frisoni, Giovanni B.; Salloway, Stephen; Van der Flier, Wiesje Maria
      Lancet (2016), 388 (10043), 505-517CODEN: LANCAO; ISSN:0140-6736. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Although the prevalence of dementia continues to increase worldwide, incidence in the western world might have decreased as a result of better vascular care and improved brain health. Alzheimer's disease, the most prevalent cause of dementia, is still defined by the combined presence of amyloid and tau, but researchers are gradually moving away from the simple assumption of linear causality as proposed in the original amyloid hypothesis. Age-related, protective, and disease-promoting factors probably interact with the core mechanisms of the disease. Amyloid β42, and tau proteins are established core cerebrospinal biomarkers; novel candidate biomarkers include amyloid β oligomers and synaptic markers. MRI and fluorodeoxyglucose PET are established imaging techniques for diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease. Amyloid PET is gaining traction in the clin. arena, but validity and cost-effectiveness remain to be established. Tau PET might offer new insights and be of great help in differential diagnosis and selection of patients for trials. In the search for understanding the disease mechanism and keys to treatment, research is moving increasingly into the earliest phase of disease. Preclin. Alzheimer's disease is defined as biomarker evidence of Alzheimer's pathol. changes in cognitively healthy individuals. Patients with subjective cognitive decline have been identified as a useful population in whom to look for preclin. Alzheimer's disease. Moderately pos. results for interventions targeting several lifestyle factors in non-demented elderly patients and moderately pos. interim results for lowering amyloid in pre-dementia Alzheimer's disease suggest that, ultimately, there will be a future in which specific anti-Alzheimer's therapy will be combined with lifestyle interventions targeting general brain health to jointly combat the disease. In this Seminar, we discuss the main developments in Alzheimer's research.

      The prion model for progression and diversity of neurodegenerative diseases
      Stopschinski, Barbara E.; Diamond, Marc I.
      Lancet Neurology (2017), 16 (4), 323-332CODEN: LNAEAM; ISSN:1474-4422. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      The neuropathol. of different neurodegenerative diseases begins in different brain regions, and involves distinct brain networks. Evidence indicates that transcellular propagation of protein aggregation, which is the basis of prion disease, might underlie the progression of pathol. in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and Huntington's disease. The prion model predicts specific patterns of neuronal vulnerability and network involvement on the basis of the conformation of pathol. proteins. Indeed, evidence indicates that self-propagating aggregate conformers, or so-called strains, are assocd. with distinct neuropathol. syndromes. The extension of this hypothesis to our understanding of common neurodegenerative disorders can suggest new therapeutic approaches, such as immunotherapy and small mols., to block transcellular propagation, and new diagnostic tools to detect early evidence of disease.

      Carbamate Derivatives of Indolines as Cholinesterase Inhibitors and Antioxidants for the Treatment of Alzheimer's Disease
      Yanovsky, Inessa; Finkin-Groner, Efrat; Zaikin, Andrey; Lerman, Lena; Shalom, Hila; Zeeli, Shani; Weill, Tehilla; Ginsburg, Isaac; Nudelman, Abraham; Weinstock, Marta
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 55 (23), 10700-10715CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      The cascade of events that occurs in Alzheimer's disease involving oxidative stress and the redn. in cholinergic transmission can be better addressed by multifunctional drugs than cholinesterase inhibitors alone. For this purpose, we prepd. a large no. of derivs. of indoline-3-propionic acids and esters. They showed scavenging activity against different radicals in soln. and significant protection against cytotoxicity in cardiomyocytes and primary cultures of neuronal cells exposed to H2O2 species and serum deprivation at concns. ranging from 1 nM to 10 μM depending on the compd.       Combining Galantamine and Memantine in Multitargeted, New Chemical Entities Potentially Useful in Alzheimer's Disease
      Simoni, Elena; Daniele, Simona; Bottegoni, Giovanni; Pizzirani, Daniela; Trincavelli, Maria L.; Goldoni, Luca; Tarozzo, Glauco; Reggiani, Angelo; Martini, Claudia; Piomelli, Daniele; Melchiorre, Carlo; Rosini, Michela; Cavalli, Andrea
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2012), 55 (22), 9708-9721CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Herein we report on a novel series of multitargeted compds. obtained by linking together galantamine and memantine. The compds. were designed by taking advantage of the crystal structures of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) in complex with galantamine derivs. Sixteen novel derivs. were synthesized, using spacers of different lengths and chem. compn. The mols. were then tested as inhibitors of AChE and as binders of the N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor (NMDAR). Some of the new compds. were nanomolar inhibitors of AChE and showed micromolar affinities for NMDAR. All compds. were also tested for selectivity toward NMDAR contg. the 2B subunit (NR2B). Some of the new derivs. showed a micromolar affinity for NR2B. Finally, selected compds. were tested using a cell-based assay to measure their neuroprotective activity. Three of them showed a remarkable neuroprotective profile, inhibiting the NMDA-induced neurotoxicity at subnanomolar concns. (e.g., 5, named memagal, IC50 = 0.28 nM).

      Donepezil is associated with delayed nursing home placement in patients with Alzheimer's disease
      Geldmacher David S; Provenzano George; McRae Thomas; Mastey Vera; Ieni John R
      Journal of the American Geriatrics Society (2003), 51 (7), 937-44 ISSN:0002-8614.
      OBJECTIVES: To assess the relationship between donepezil treatment and time to nursing home placement (NHP) for patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD). DESIGN: Observational follow-up of patient NHP and vital status. SETTING: Community. PARTICIPANTS: Patients previously enrolled in one of three randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trials of donepezil and two subsequent open-label studies (total N = 1,115); 671 patients provided complete data for analysis. MEASUREMENTS: Data were obtained through follow-up interviews with caregivers and chart reviews of patients with AD. Comparison groups were defined by whether patients received an effective dose of donepezil (>/=5 mg/d; >/=80% compliance) for specific numbers of weeks during the double-blind or open-label trial phase, in both phases, or in neither. Cox proportional hazards models were used to estimate risk ratios for NHP and survival curves from which median times to NHP were estimated for first dementia-related placement of longer than 2 weeks and permanent placement. The models were adjusted for age, sex, baseline Mini-Mental State Examination score, whether the caregiver was a spouse, caregiver continuity, and use of other cholinesterase inhibitors after the clinical trials. RESULTS: Use of donepezil of 5 mg/d or more was associated with significant delays in NHP. A cumulative dose-response relationship was observed between longer-term sustained donepezil use and delay of NHP. When donepezil was taken at an effective dose for at least 9 to 12 months, conservative estimates of the time gained before NHP were 21.4 months for first dementia-related NHP and 17.5 months for permanent NHP. CONCLUSION: Use of donepezil by AD patients resulted in significant delays in NHP. Long-term use of donepezil may help AD patients live longer in community settings, with consequent personal, social, and economic benefits.

      A 5-month, randomized, placebo-controlled trial of galantamine in AD
      Tariot, P. N.; Solomon, P. R.; Morris, J. C.; Kershaw, P.; Lilienfeld, S.; Ding, C.; Ahern, G.; Aronson, S.; Brenner, R.; Burke, W.; Cochran, J.; Cohen, S.; Cummins, H.; Drachman, D.; Duboff, E.; Farlow, M.; Ferris, S.; Forchetti, C.; Frey, J.; Grossberg, G.; Harrell, L.; Hoffstetter, M.; Holub, R.; Kaye, J.; Landbloom, R.; Levin, K.; Lindahl, L.; Londborg, P.; Lyketsos, C.; Maguire, G.; Mallya, G.; Merideth, C.; Mintzer, J.; Morris, J.; Newhouse, P.; Ng, K.; Plopper, M.; Porteinsson, A.; Probst, T.; Raskind, M.; Reichman, W.; Richardson, B.; Richter, R.; Ross, J.; Sadowsky, C.; Saur, D.; Sauter, M.; Scharre, D.; Schindler, R.; Schneider, L.; Scinto, L.; Siegal, A.; Smith, W.; Solomon, P.; Steinberg, A.; Stone, W.; Tariot, P. N.; Thein, S.; Van Dyck, C.; Visser, J.; Walshe, T., III; Weiner, M.; West, S.
      Neurology (2000), 54 (12), 2269-2276CODEN: NEURAI; ISSN:0028-3878. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      The efficacy and tolerability of galantamine, using a slow dose escalation schedule of up to 8 wk, were evaluated in 978 patients with mild to moderate AD. The study consisted of a 5-mo multicenter, placebo-controlled, double-blind trial. Following a 4-wk placebo run-in, patients were randomized to one of four treatment arms: placebo or galantamine escalated to final maintenance doses of 8, 16, or 24 mg/day. Outcome measures included the cognitive subscale of the AD Assessment Scale (ADAS-cog), the Clinician's Interview-Based Impression of Change plus Caregiver Input (CIBIC-plus), the AD Cooperative Study Activities of Daily Living inventory, and the Neuropsychiatric Inventory. Std. safety evaluations and adverse event monitoring were carried out. After 5 mo, the galantamine-placebo differences on ADAS-cog were 3.3 points for the 16 mg/day group and 3.6 points for the 24 mg/day group (p < 0.001 vs. placebo, both doses). Compared with placebo, the galantamine 16- and 24-mg/day groups also had a significantly better outcome on CIBIC-plus, activities of daily living, and behavioral symptoms. Treatment discontinuations due to adverse events were low in all galantamine groups (6 to 10%) and comparable with the discontinuation rate in the placebo group (7%). The incidence of adverse events in the galantamine groups, notably gastrointestinal symptoms, was low and most adverse events were mild. Galantamine 16 and 24 mg/day significantly benefits the cognitive, functional, and behavioral symptoms of AD as compared with placebo. Slow dose escalation appears to enhance the tolerability of galantamine, minimizing the incidence and severity of adverse events.

      Requirement of JNK for stress-induced activation of the cytochrome c-mediated death pathway
      Tournier, Cathhy; Hess, Patricia; Yang, Derek D.; Xu, Jie; Turner, Tod K.; Nimnual, Anjaruwee; Bar-Sagi, Dafna; Jones, Stephen N.; Flavell, Richard A.; Davis, Roger J.
      Science (Washington, D. C.) (2000), 288 (5467), 870-874CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      The c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase (JNK) is activated when cells are exposed to UV radiation. However, the functional consequence of JNK activation in UV-irradiated cells has not been established. It is shown here that JNK is required for UV-induced apoptosis in primary murine embryonic fibroblasts. Fibroblasts with simultaneous targeted disruptions of all the functional Jnk genes were protected against UV-stimulated apoptosis. The absence of JNK caused a defect in the mitochondrial death signaling pathway, including the failure to release cytochrome c. These data indicate that mitochondria are influenced by proapoptotic signal transduction through the JNK pathway.

      Nuclear and cytosolic JNK signalling in neurons
      Coffey, Eleanor T.
      Nature Reviews Neuroscience (2014), 15 (5), 285-299CODEN: NRNAAN; ISSN:1471-003X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. It has been over 20 years since JUN amino-terminal kinases (JNKs) were identified as protein kinases that are strongly activated by cellular stress and that have a key role in apoptosis. Examn. of Jnk-knockout mice and characterization of JNK behavior in neuronal cells has further revealed the importance of the JNK family in the nervous system. As well as regulating neuronal death, JNKs govern brain morphogenesis and axodendritic architecture during development, and regulate important neuron-specific functions such as synaptic plasticity and memory formation. This Review examines the evidence that the spatial segregation of JNKs in neurons underlies their distinct functions and that compartment-specific targeting of JNKs may offer promising new therapeutic avenues for the treatment of diseases of the nervous system, such as stroke and neurodegenerative disorders.

      Selective interaction of JNK protein kinase isoforms with transcription factors
      Gupta, Shashi; Barret, Tamera; Whitmarsh, Alan J.; Cavanagh, Julie; Sluss, Hayla K.; Derijard, Benoit; Davis, Roger J.
      EMBO Journal (1996), 15 (11), 2760-2770CODEN: EMJODG; ISSN:0261-4189. (Oxford University Press)
      The JNK protein kinase is a member of the MAP kinase group that is activated in response to dual phosphorylation on threonine and tyrosine. Ten JNK isoforms were identified in human brain by mol. cloning. These protein kinases correspond to alternatively spliced isoforms derived from the JNK1, JNK2 and JNK3 genes. The protein kinase activity of these JNK isoforms was measured using the transcription factors ATF2, Elk-1 and members of the Jun family as substrates. Treatment of cells with interleukin-1 (IL-1) caused activation of the JNK isoforms. This activation was blocked by expression of the MAP kinase phosphatase MKP-1. Comparison of the binding activity of the JNK isoforms demonstrated that the JNK proteins differ in their interaction with ATF2, Elk-1 and Jun transcription factors. Individual members of the JNK group may therefore selectively target specific transcription factors in vivo.

      Context-specific inhibition of JNKs: overcoming the dilemma of protection and damage
      Waetzig, Vicki; Herdegen, Thomas
      Trends in Pharmacological Sciences (2005), 26 (9), 455-461CODEN: TPHSDY; ISSN:0165-6147. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. The c-Jun N-terminal kinases (JNKs), which are essential regulators of physiol. and pathol. processes, are involved in several diseases including diabetes, atherosclerosis, stroke, and Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases. Inhibition of JNKs suppresses pathol. features of these diseases but the many physiol. functions of these enzymes argue against the use of sustained, systemic, nonspecific inhibition in the treatment of these diseases. For example, deletion of the gene that encodes JNK1 prevents insulin resistance but disrupts neuronal cytoarchitecture and initiates the pathol. of Alzheimer's disease. Thus, it is not sufficient to inhibit selectively either JNKs or individual isoforms of JNK. Instead, the aim is to inhibit the damaging actions of JNK. This can be achieved using peptides that selectively target mol. domains of individual JNK signaling complexes (exclusively) that form under pathol. conditions. To date, peptide inhibitors of JNK have been successful in protecting against ischemia-induced brain damage and insulin resistance following obesity. In this review, we discuss novel pharmacol. strategies to inhibit JNK and the limitations of these strategies.

      NGF controls APP cleavage by downregulating APP phosphorylation at Thr668: relevance for Alzheimer's disease
      Triaca, Viviana; Sposato, Valentina; Bolasco, Giulia; Ciotti, Maria Teresa; Pelicci, Piergiuseppe; Bruni, Amalia C.; Cupidi, Chiara; Maletta, Raffaele; Feligioni, Marco; Nistico, Robert; Canu, Nadia; Calissano, Pietro

      Pseudophosphorylation of tau at serine 422 inhibits caspase cleavage: in vitro evidence and implications for tangle formation in vivo
      Guillozet-Bongaarts, Angela L.; Cahill, Michael E.; Cryns, Vincent L.; Reynolds, Matthew R.; Berry, Robert W.; Binder, Lester I.
      Journal of Neurochemistry (2006), 97 (4), 1005-1014CODEN: JONRA9; ISSN:0022-3042. (Blackwell Publishing Ltd.)
      The tangles of Alzheimer's disease (AD) are comprised of the tau protein displaying numerous alterations, including phosphorylation at serine 422 (S422) and truncation at aspartic acid 421 (D421). Truncation at the latter site appears to result from activation of caspases, a class of proteases that cleave specifically at aspartic acid residues. It has been proposed that phosphorylation at or near caspase cleavage sites could regulate the ability of the protease to cleave at those sites. Here, we use tau pseudophosphorylated at S422 (S422E) to examine the effects of tau phosphorylation on its cleavage by caspase 3. We find that S422E tau is more resistant to proteolysis by caspase 3 than non-pseudophosphorylated tau. Addnl., we use antibodies directed against the phosphorylation site and against the truncation epitope to assess the presence of these epitopes in neurofibrillary tangles in the aged human brain. We show that phosphorylation precedes truncation during tangle maturation. Moreover, the distribution of the two epitopes suggests that a significant length of time (perhaps as much as two decades) elapses between S422 phosphorylation and cleavage at D421. We further conclude that tau phosphorylation at S422 may be a protective mechanism that inhibits cleavage in vivo.

      JNK Inhibition Protects Dopamine Neurons and Provides Behavioral Improvement in a Rat 6-Hydroxydopamine Model of Parkinson's Disease

      Parkinson's disease (PD) results from the loss of dopamine neurons located in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNpc) that project to the striatum.       SP600125, an anthrapyrazolone inhibitor of Jun N-terminal kinase
      Bennett, Brydon L.; Sasaki, Dennis T.; Murray, Brion W.; O'Leary, Eoin C.; Sakata, Steve T.; Xu, Weiming; Leisten, Jim C.; Motiwala, Aparna; Pierce, Steve; Satoh, Yoshitaka; Bhagwat, Shripad S.; Manning, Anthony M.; Anderson, David W.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2001), 98 (24), 13681-13686CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) is a stress-activated protein kinase that can be induced by inflammatory cytokines, bacterial endotoxin, osmotic shock, UV radiation, and hypoxia. We report the identification of an anthrapyrazolone series with significant inhibition of JNK1, -2, and -3 (Ki = 0.19 μM). SP600125 is a reversible ATP-competitive inhibitor with >20-fold selectivity vs. a range of kinases and enzymes tested. In cells, SP600125 dose-dependently inhibited the phosphorylation of c-Jun, the expression of inflammatory genes COX-2, IL-2, IFN-γ, TNF-α, and prevented the activation and differentiation of primary human CD4 cell cultures. In animal studies, SP600125 blocked (bacterial) lipopolysaccharide-induced expression of tumor necrosis factor-α and inhibited anti-CD3-induced apoptosis of CD4+ CD8+ thymocytes. Our study supports targeting JNK as an important strategy in inflammatory disease, apoptotic cell death, and cancer.

      The specific, reversible JNK inhibitor SP600125 improves survivability and attenuates neuronal cell death in experimental cerebral malaria (ECM)
      Anand Sripada Santosh; Maruthi Mulaka; Babu Phanithi Prakash
      Parasitology research (2013), 112 (5), 1959-66 ISSN:.
      Cerebral malaria (CM) is the most severe complication of Plasmodium falciparum in humans and major cause of death. SP600125 is a specific, small molecule inhibitor of JNK that prevents the phosphorylation of c-Jun and blocks the expression of proinflammatory cytokines and attenuates neuronal apoptosis in several neurodegenerative disorders. We evaluated the effect of SP600125 treatment on the survival of Plasmodium berghei ANKA (PbA)-infected C57BL/6J mice. Administration of SP600125 improved survival in PbA-infected C57BL6J mice but has no effect on parasitemia. Further, SP600125 administration resulted in attenuation of neuronal cell death along with inhibition of proinflammatory mediators TNF-α and COX-2 and proapoptotic mediators p-c-Jun and active caspase 3 in PbA-infected mice. The promising findings of this study make SP600125 a potential agent for supportive therapy to alleviate inflammation and neuronal cell death associated with CM.

      Designing heterocyclic selective kinase inhibitors: from concept to new drug candidates
      Halazy, Serge
      ARKIVOC (Gainesville, FL, United States) (2006), (7), 496-508CODEN: AGFUAR ISSN:. (Arkat USA Inc.)
      Kinases represent one of the most popular and promising target class in drug discovery. Success in finding new therapeutics will depend on the validation of the kinase chosen with respect to the disease of interest, and on the ability of chemists to design and synthesize inhibitors which are selective for this particular kinase. One of the most powerful validation tool for kinases is the Analog-Sensitive Kinase Allele (ASKA) technol., where chemists and biologists have engineered modified kinases and inhibitors by generating functionally active kinase mutants which are specifically inhibited by a chem. modified inhibitor, thus allowing to study specific responses in knock-in animals. The design of selective, ATP competitive kinase inhibitors has been successfully achieved by combining different technologies like computational chem., structure-based design and combinatorial chem. as illustrated by the discovery of AS602801, a potent and selective JNK inhibitor with therapeutic potential in MS and fibrosis. The exploration of non ATP-competitive inhibitors is also very promising, as illustrated by the case of MEK inhibitors which show strong interest as anti-cancer agents. In the future, the rationale design of selective kinase inhibitors will move to the design of compds. that will induce a selective perturbation of cell regulation, where kinases play a crit. role.
